indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. no. of schools with biomass boilers totalling 5200 tCO2e in direct emissions reductions 2. no. of regions where business model has been replicated 3. amount of sustainably sourced biomass fuelwood supplied at competitive price 4. reduction of perceptions of fuel supply risk based on consumer confidence survey 5. percentage increase in biomass energy awareness and capacity in project area

baseline.comment: 1. (0) zero schools with biomass boilers 2. (0) zero regions where business model has been replicated 3. (0) amount of sustainably sourced â€“ certified biomass fuelwood supply 4. (0) perceptions of fuel supply risk not recorded-no consumer confidence survey 5. (0) no impact surveys on awareness, perceptions and capacity of biomass energy

target.comment: 1. Minimum 2 schools with new biomass boilers installed and emissions reductions calculated for installations up-to-date. 2. 2 municipalities - Heat service contracting to be promoted and replicated in additional 2 municipalities. 3. 200t of sustainably sourced biomass fuelwood supplied 4. Perceptions of fuel supply risk recorded and presented to minimum 50 stakeholders 5. Awareness, perception and capacity of biomass energy score increases by 10%, compared to baseline survey

actual.comment: 1. 2 schools with new biomass boilers installed and emissions reductions calculated and amounting to 900 tCO2e. 2. 2 municipalities -Biomass fuel switch promoted and replicated in additional 2 municipalities through other E&E projects. 3. 200t of sustainably sourced biomass fuel-wood supplied to project boilers 4. 1 study results presented to over 70 stakeholders - Assessment on possibilities of using biomass in B&H compiled and presented to stakeholders, scientific community, private sector and investors. 5. Awareness and perception of biomass energy increased by 33,7% and 30% on two separate surveying processes. (completed in 2012)

target.comment: 1. Minimum 1 other public facility with new biomass boiler installed. 2. Minimum 4 additional regions/municipalities with replicated model of biomass fuel-switch with minimum of 7 additional facilities included through other Energy and Environment projects. 3. Minimum one promotional/awareness (i.e. study tour or workshop) activity conducted for the private sector.

actual.comment: 1. One Cantonal hospital with new biomass boiler installed (2nd largest fuel switch project conducted) 2.Minimum 4 other regions with replicated model (Doboj municipality,Unsko Sanski Canton, Zapadno Hercegovacki Canton, Banja Luka municipality) and 12 additional facilities with biomass fuel-switch projects completed through other E&E projects 3. Study tour organized for the representatives of private sector (biomass producers - members of the biomass association) to the Czech republic - transfer of knowledge and experience from the Czech

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of trained energy professionals. 2. Number of cantons that introduced institutionalization of energy, costs and emission management and monitoring in public sector buildings of BiH imposed. 3. Number of sustainable financial mechanisms within Environmental Protection Funds developed and adopted. 4. Number of public buildings where energy efficiency measures were implemented. 5. Number of energy efficiency campaigns executed.

target.comment: 30 detailed energy audits assessed, prioritized and ranked by Environment Funds 100 energy professionals participating on training programme for skills and knowledge development 30 female energy professionals participated on training programme for skills and knowledge development 30 detailed energy audits conducted 5 investment decisions made based on evaluation of detailed energy audits 10 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) participating on annual capacity development training on energy efficiency, EMIS and EE policy 2 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) actively working on EMIS/EE investment decision making process cycle, monitoring, assessing and evaluating energy indicators 100 public sector buildings monitored through EMIS database 1000 end-users trained on EMIS 5 EE infrastructure projects implemented with grant co-financing modality 5 effectively implemented EE infrastructure projects in public sector buildings 50 % of total energy consumption savings within implemented public sector buildings 260t of direct CO2 emission reduction 85 of generated man-months â€œgreen jobsâ€ Amount of co-financing infrastructure projects during SIDAâ€™s involvement 5 end-users/institutions reinvesting generated savings into other infrastructure projects Media campaign outreach achieved (18000seconds) 15 awareness raising events held in BiH 3000 promotional materials distributed 10000 of people reached through marketing campaign 300 of posts at GED public awareness campaign social networks (professor Atom) Change of attitudes and perception on EE of targeted audiences (children age 13+, youth and general public)in targeted 15 cities countrywideâ€“ measured using pre and post campaign survey, using questionnaires and online surveying tools (qualitative and qualitative)

actual.comment: 37 detailed energy audits assessed, prioritized and ranked by Environment Funds 100 energy professionals participating on training programme for skills and knowledge development 30 female energy professionals participated on training programme for skills and knowledge development 30 detailed energy audits conducted 5 investment decisions made based on evaluation of detailed energy audits 10 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) participating on annual capacity development training on energy efficiency, EMIS and EE policy 2 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) actively working on EMIS/EE investment decision making process cycle, monitoring, assessing and evaluating energy indicators 100 public sector buildings monitored through EMIS database 1000 end-users trained on EMIS 5 EE infrastructure projects implemented with grant co-financing modality 5 effectively implemented EE infrastructure projects in public sector buildings 50 % of total energy consumption savings within implemented public sector buildings 260t of direct CO2 emission reduction 85 of generated man-months â€œgreen jobsâ€ Amount of co-financing infrastructure projects during SIDAâ€™s involvement 5 end-users/institutions reinvesting generated savings into other infrastructure projects Media campaign outreach achieved (18000seconds) 15 awareness raising events held in BiH 3000 promotional materials distributed 10000 of people reached through marketing campaign 300 of posts at GED public awareness campaign social networks (professor Atom) Change of attitudes and perception on EE of targeted audiences (children age 13+, youth and general public)in targeted 15 cities countrywideâ€“ measured using pre and post campaign survey, using questionnaires and online surveying tools (qualitative and qualitative)

target.comment: 30 detailed energy audits assessed, prioritized and ranked by Environment Funds 100 energy professionals participating on training programme for skills and knowledge development 30 female energy professionals participated on training programme for skills and knowledge development 30 detailed energy audits conducted 5 investment decisions made based on evaluation of detailed energy audits 10 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) participating on annual capacity development training on energy efficiency, EMIS and EE policy 2 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) actively working on EMIS/EE investment decision making process cycle, monitoring, assessing and evaluating energy indicators 100 public sector buildings monitored through EMIS database 1000 end-users trained on EMIS 15 EE infrastructure projects implemented with grant co-financing modality 5 effectively implemented EE infrastructure projects in public sector buildings 50 % of total energy consumption savings within implemented public sector buildings 260t of direct CO2 emission reduction 85 of generated man-months â€œgreen jobsâ€ Amount of co-financing infrastructure projects during SIDAâ€™s involvement 5 end-users/institutions reinvesting generated savings into other infrastructure projects Media campaign outreach achieved (18000seconds) 15 awareness raising events held in BiH 3000 promotional materials distributed 10000 of people reached through marketing campaign 300 of posts at GED public awareness campaign social networks (professor Atom) Change of attitudes and perception on EE of targeted audiences (children age 13+, youth and general public)in targeted 15 cities countrywideâ€“ measured using pre and post campaign survey, using questionnaires and online surveying tools (qualitative and qualitative)

actual.comment: 36 detailed energy audits assessed, prioritized and ranked by Environment Funds za rangiranje posmatrani I oni ranije 233 energy professionals participating on training programme for skills and knowledge development 100 female energy professionals participated on training programme for skills and knowledge development 42 detailed energy audits conducted 24 investment decisions made based on evaluation of detailed energy audits 5 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) participating on annual capacity development training on energy efficiency, EMIS and EE policy 2 Fund staff (FBiH and RS each) actively working on EMIS/EE investment decision making process cycle, monitoring, assessing and evaluating energy indicators 2197 public sector buildings monitored through EMIS database 1842 end-users trained on EMIS 25 EE infrastructure projects implemented with grant co-financing modality 25 effectively implemented EE infrastructure projects in public sector buildings 51,46 % of total energy consumption savings within implemented public sector buildings 1.851 t of direct CO2 emission reduction 350 of generated man-months â€œgreen jobsâ€ 2.200.000 BAM (mislim) Amount of co-financing infrastructure projects during SIDAâ€™s involvement 24 end-users/institutions reinvesting generated savings into other infrastructure projects Media campaign outreach achieved (15.480 seconds) 15 awareness raising events held in Bosnia and Herzegovina 33.000 promotional materials distributed 500.000 of people reached through marketing campaign 675 of posts at Green Economic Development public awareness campaign social networks (professor Atom) Change of attitudes and perception on energy efficiencyof targeted audiences (children age 13+, youth and general public)in targeted 15 cities countrywideâ€“ measured using pre and post campaign survey, using questionnaires and online surveying tools (qualitative and qualitative)

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of newly established and opened Victim Witness Support offices. 2. Number of Memorandums of Understanding signed with partner institutions, incorporating victim witness support in justice administration. 3. Number of Rulebooks on Internal Procedures for Victim Support Offices.

baseline.comment: 1. 8 Victim Witness Support offices opened and functional. 2. 10 Memorandums of Understanding signed with partner institutions, incorporating victim witness support in justice administration. 3. 5 Rulebooks on Internal Procedures for Victim Support Offices.

target.comment: 1. 3- Three Victim and Witness Support Services/Offices in the courts/prosecutors' offices in Herzegovina-Neretva Canton and Brcko District (two in HNK and one in Brcko). 2. 4- Memorandums of Understanding signed with partner institutions, incorporating victim witness support in justice administration. 3. 4- Rulebooks on Internal Procedures for Victim Support Offices.

actual.comment: 1. 3 WSOs opened in in Herzegovina-Neretva Canton and Brcko District with support provided to the work of prosecutors and courts in those jurisdictions. 2. 5 Memorandums of Understanding signed with partner institutions, incorporating victim witness support in justice administration, including an additional memorandum signed between Brcko District Police Department and Brcko District Prosecutor's Office. 3. 4 Rulebooks on Internal Procedures for Victim Support Offices developed and institutionalized.

target.comment: 1. 2 Victim and Witness Support Services/Offices in the courts/prosecutors' offices in Zenica Doboj Canton. 2. 2- Memorandums of Understanding signed with partner institutions, incorporating victim witness support in justice administration. 3. 2- Rulebooks on Internal Procedures for Victim Support Offices developed and instituionalized.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of desk review/map of stakeholders prepared. 2. Number of studies for establishment of a regulatory framework. 3. Number of methodologies for setting water supply and wastewater tariffs.

target.comment: 1. Finalize assessment on establishment of regulatory framework on water and sanitation tariff settings 2. Develop action plan for implementation of recommendations 3. Prepare draft methodology for setting water supply and wastewater tariffs 4. Prepare draft study on the best administrative positioning of intended Legal Bodies for Tariffs Evaluation and compliance with the prescribed methodology

actual.comment: 1. One finalized assessment on establishment of regulatory framework on water and sanitation tariff settings 2. One action plan for implementation of recommendations developed. 3. Prepared draft methodology for setting water supply and wastewater tariffs. 4. Prepared draft study on the best administrative positioning of intended Legal Bodies for Tariffs Evaluation and compliance with the prescribed methodology.

target.comment: 1. Finalize the methodology for setting water supply and wastewater tariffs. 2. Finalize study on the best administrative positioning of intended Legal Bodies for Tariffs Evaluation and compliance with the prescribed methodology. 3. Organize validation workshop for documents finalization.

actual.comment: 1. Finalized methodology for setting water supply and wastewater tariffs 2. Finalized study on the best administrative positioning of intended Legal Bodies for Tariffs Evaluation and compliance with the prescribed methodology 3. Validation workshop held

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of value chains analysed and effectively supported to increase productivity. 2. Percentage increase in productivity in selected value chains. 3. Percentage increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 4. Number of returnee families included in selected value chains.

baseline.comment: 1. 0 2. Low productivity in agricultural / food producing value chains. 3. Average personal income EUR 395. 4. 0

target.comment: 1. Conduct value chains analysis in 5 regions and identify 5 most potent value chains. 2. Ensure at least 5% increase in productivity in selected value chains. 3. Ensure at least 10 % increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 4. Support at least 80 returnees and IDPs to benefit from income generation assistance.

actual.comment: 1. Conducted value chains analysis in 5 regions and identified 6 most potent value chains for further assistance. 2. 5 % increase in productivity in selected value chains. 3. 22 % increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 4.120 returnees/IDPs families benefited from income generation activities.

target.comment: 1. Ensure at least 5% increase in productivity in selected 6 value chains through linkage of at least 6 new SMEs to the value chains, support to 5 agricultural service providers and assistance for better marketing and promotion. 2. Ensure at least 10 % increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 3. Ensure at least 5 % increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 4. Support at least 20 additional returnees and IDPs by engagement in income generation activities.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. % of investments in support to competitiveness. 2. % increase of officially registered employees in the region compared to the average for Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. % increase of revenues in retail trade. 4. Difference between the average gross income of rural families and the average gross salary. 5. Number of effective and functional public-private dialogue mechanisms.

baseline.comment: 1. Limited competitiveness of the Srebrenica region (to be calculated at the beginning of the project). 2. 5,139 officially registered employees in the region (2012). 3. Turnover of retail trade amounts to BAM 48,606,000 in 2012. 4. Average gross income of rural families is 50% lower than the average gross salary (around BAM 1,200). 5. No structured dialogue between the public and private sectors.

target.comment: 1. 5% compared to 2013. 2. 1%. 3. 2%. 4. 45% lower than the average gross salary. 5. 3 effective and functional public-private dialogue mechanisms established.
1. 10% compared to 2013. 2. 5% compared to 2013. 3. At least 2% higher. 4. 35% lower than the average gross salary. 5. Implemented at least three initiatives proposed by the PPD working groups.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.Number of organized disaster risk reduction platforms organized in BiH resulting in enhanced capacities of responsible institutions from all levels of government. 2. Number of educational events aimed at increased understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area 3. Level of Capacities and conditions under which Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH operate. 4. Number of roaming dog management plans adopted in selected municipalities in BiH.

baseline.comment: 1. Disaster Risk Reduction policy of BiH is decentralized to all levels of government with different government levels without clear roles and responsibilities and with limited coordination. 2. Lack of understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area. 3. Insufficient level of equipment at disposal by Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH 4. No roaming dog management plans adopted in Lopare and Sanski Most.

target.comment: 1. One State and entities disaster risk reduction platforms organized 2. Three educational events organized to increase the understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area 3. Develop one plan and one study in the area of disaster risk reduction, highlighting the existing social inequalities, the impact these have on the lives of the many women and socially excluded, vulnerable population groups 4. Two roaming dog management plans adopted in Lopare and Sanski Most.

actual.comment: 1. One State BiH Disaster Risk Reduction Platform was completed in December 2014. 2. Three educational events organized including 112 Round Table, Host Nations Support Training for Emergency Coordination Body and Floods Conference 3. Improved capacities and conditions by targeted equipping of Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH for Mine Action Clearance activities in BiH. 4. Based on approved plans, International Fund Animal Welfare supported equipping local veterinary clinic in Lopare to implement one of two adopted plans Sterilization and Castration of roaming a dogs.

target.comment: 1. Develop one plan in the area of disaster risk reduction targeted at fire protection prevention activities. 2. Development of evidence based disaster risk profiles for seven cantons and four municipalities based on the existing national hazard risk assessment in BiH. 3. Development of Disaster Risk Reduction Training Programme and ToT Module integrating DRR into local policies and strategies. 4.Implementation of the Humane Community Development plans in municipalities of Sanski Most, Jajce and Gradacac 5. Assessment of capacities of City of Mostar in Humane Community Development. 6. Equipping of Vet clinics in Sanski Most, Jajce and Gradacac to undertake sterilization and castration in line with IFAW standards in humane handling with animals 7. Full implementation of Humane Community Development plan in Lopare and report from Municipality on achieved progress.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Project started in 2015. 1. Quality of water management in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment in order to identify weak points and appropriate measures for improvement. 2. Coordination between partners at local, state, entity, cantonal and local government levels enhanced through joint design of concrete initiatives for the Main Phase. 3. Quality of business friendly environment and economic conditions in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment.

baseline.comment:
Project started in 2015.
1. Poor quality of water management and infrastructure in local governments leads to distribution losses of up to 50 %, increasing cost of water. 2. Insufficient coordination between local governments, water utilities, sectoral ministries at entity and cantonal levels for the sake of better service delivery management capacity and accountability. 3. Despite positive experiences, including pilot â€œbusiness-friendlyâ€ certification, local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina still lack sound economic expertise and tools to engage in productive public-private dialogue and increase investment attractiveness of their localities through viable business infrastructure, support to employability and local entrepreneurship.

target.comment: Project started in 2015. 1. Assessment of institutional, operational and financial capacities of water utilities in at least 25 selected local governments conducted, and possible measures defined. 2. Concrete initiatives for the Main Phase designed stemming from at least 6 coordination meetings between UNDP and representatives of relevant institutions on local, entity, and state level. 3. Assessment of business friendly environment in at least 25 selected local governments conducted. 4. Full fledged document for the Main Phase prepared.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Indicator for Objective 1: Number of dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,000). Number of vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home (target value: 15,400). Number of comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Indicator for Objective 2: Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped: target value Number of children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas Number of municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas Number of healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas Number of social welfare facilities in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services Number of child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for children in affected areas Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure km of local roads and number of bridges in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed Number of households in flood-affected areas benefiting directly from improved water and sanitation services.
Indicator for Objective 3: Number of jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas Number of MSMEs supported to restore economic activity Number of a

baseline.comment:
Baseline for Objective 1: 39,231 damaged homes in BiH.
Baseline for Objective 2: 120 educational facilities, 8 municipal buildings damaged; Recovery Needs Assessment and based on data recorded by the enterprise survey, an additional 33,500 wage workers were directly affected by the floods and are at immediate risk. Additional information received after the conclusion of the enterprise survey by the Ministry of Labour and Veterans of RS stated that approximately 20,000 jobs remain at risk in RS due to the flood.
Baseline for Objective 3: 81 affected local governments benefiting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Recovery Needs Assessment (2014).

target.comment:
Targets for Objective 1: to repair 1,000 dwellings in flood-affected areas to return home 3,500 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas
Targets for Objective 2: to rehabilitate 50 flood-affected local governments by rehabilitating public services and infrastructure to rehabilitate and reequip 70 educational institutions in affected areas to rehabilitate 2 municipal public administration facilities in affected areas to rehabilitate 4 healthcare facilities in affected areas to rehabilitate 4 social welfare facilities in flood-affected areas to construct 20 child-friendly spaces ensuring temporary learning and playing facilities for children in affected areas to rehabilitate 25 local roads and bridges in flood-affected areas to reconstruct 5 critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas
Targets for Objective 3: to create or retain 2,000 jobs in agriculture and local businesses in affected areas to support 20 MSMEs in restoring economic activity

actual.comment:
Results for Objective 1: 1,008 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired 3,528 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home
Results for Objective 2: 50 flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure 65 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped 2 municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 3 healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 4 social welfare facilities in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 20 child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for children in affected areas 26 local roads and bridges in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 6 critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed.
Results for Objective 3: 1,861 jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas 56 MSMEs supported to restore economic activity

target.comment:
Targets for Objective 1: 3,400 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,400). 11,900 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home/resume life in normal living conditions Comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Targets for Objective 2: 47 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped 4 flood-affected locations mitigated in terms of landslide and flood risk 10 rehabilitated public buildings with increased energy efficiency 45,000 children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas 3 municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 210,000 citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas. 2 healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 210,000 citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas 1 social welfare facility in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 55,000 representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services 4 child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for 2, 000 children in affected areas and number of children benefiting 11 km of local roads and bridges (in total number of 74) in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 25 critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed
Targets for objective 3: 1,674 jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas 39 MSMEs supported to restore economic activity 700 commercial agriculture households linked into the local market value chain (grain producers, subsistence farmers, poultry farmers and raspberry producers)

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Increased sustainability and resilience of the flood affected population and institutions through targeted assistance in a number of vital recovery areas: 1500 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers equipped with medical equipment and vehicles 100 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems dairy value chain improved in the canton zenica-doboj through targeted assistance to affected households and reconstruction of milk collection points and farms

baseline.comment: The natural disaster affected a quarter of the territory approximately one million people and some 27% of the country's population of 3.8 million. Nearly 50%of municipalities were hit by the floods, 46 of which have suffered severe damage and destruction, where urban, industrial and rural areas were completely flooded with water, cut off and without electricity, drinkable water or communication for days. Some 50,000 homes have been damaged or flooded leading to evacuation of 40,000 persons and loss of over 15,000 persons.

target.comment: Increased sustainability and resilience of the flood affected population and institutions through targeted assistance in a number of vital recovery areas: 1000 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers identified medical equipment needs and priorities 50 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems

actual.comment: Increased sustainability and resilience of the flood affected population and institutions through targeted assistance in a number of vital recovery areas: 1297households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers identified medical equipment needs and priorities 76 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems

target.comment: 1500 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers equipped with medical equipment and vehicles 76 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems dairy value chain improved in the canton zenica-doboj through targeted assistance to affected households and reconstruction of milk collection points and farms

iati-activity.title: Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
iati-activity.description: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

document-link.title: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

iati-activity.title: Climate-resilient flood mgmt
iati-activity.description: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Project started in 2015.
1. Number of new technologies transferred to Bosnia and Herzegovina as part of a methodology for strategic flood risk management. 2. Vrbas river basin (12% of BiH territory) covered by an automated hydrometric monitoring network for effective Flood Forecasting and Early Warning. 3. Policy environment and regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer established or strengthened 4. Strengthened Capacity to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies 5. Number of institutions enabled to modify risk management strategies based on introduced vulnerability, loss and damages assessment and improved hydrometric monitoring technologies 6. Number of people in target basin benefiting from flood risk management adaptation technologies, tools, and adaptation strategies, and are less exposed to flood risk 7. Availability of innovative non-structural measures introduced and implemented as part of climate adaptation strategies to provide improved resilience to communities (include agric. 8. Number of communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding

baseline.comment:
Project started in 2015.
1. 0 strategic flood risk management technologies in Bosnia and Herzegovina 2. No automatized and centralized hydrometric network in Vrbas river basin 3. No policy/regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer in place 4. Local professionals are unaware of adaptation technologies 5. Most of the socio-economic information required to assess flood damages, losses, exposure and vulnerability is not currently available and is not collected systematically and gender-disaggregation of data not systematically done. 6.Current approach limited of inclusion of local communities, and particularly the vulnerable groups 7.Current approach to flood risk management is structural flood protection measures and non-structural measures are not considered to be adaptive measure. 8. 0 communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding.

target.comment:
Project started in 2015
1. Establish inter-agency working group on climate changes and flood risk management 2. Rehabilitate hydro-metric network in Vrbas River Basin 3. Complete modeling on climate change impact in Vrbas River Basin 4. Develop spatial data infrastructure for Vrbas River Basin

actual.comment: 1. Inter-agency working group on climate changes and flood risk management consisting of representatives of water agencies, hydro-meteorological institutes and geodetic institutes established. 2. Hydro-metric network in Vrbas River Basin, consisting of 28 gauges, established. 3. Models on climate change impact in Vrbas River Basin developed. 4. Spatial data infrastructure, including geoportal, for Vrbas River Basin established.

document-link.title: Landslide Disaster Risk Management in Bosnia and Herzegovina_rev
Landslides Disasster and Floods Risk Mangement in BiH project

iati-activity.title: Landslide Disaster Risk Mgmt
iati-activity.description: The project aims to strengthen capacities of local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina for landslide risk mitigation. The intervention will provide support to 9 landslide- and flood-affected local governments to remediate and stabilise landslides.

country-budget-items.budget-item: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator

target.comment: Project started in 2015. 1. At least 10 landslides covering at least 600,000 m2 are remediated within partner local governments. 2. At least 4,400 people and 1,200 housing units with restored safe living conditions and livelihoods by end of March 2016. 3. 9 local governments put land risk mitigation implementation measures in place by the end of March 2016. 4. At least 1 standard practical manual disseminated to all local governments. 5. At least 27 local government staff from target local governments received practical technical and training assistance. 6. Landslide Institutional and Policy Analysis for Bosnia and Herzegovina conducted.

actual.comment: Project started in 2015. 1. 9 landslides are rehabilitated within partner local governments. 2. More than 300 housing units with restored safe living conditions and livelihoods by end of 2015. 3. 9 local governments trained and equipped for establishment of landslide risk cadasters
